obsidian.learn¶

Modules¶

obsidian.learn.convnet¶

Module of Classes and methods for building, training and handling classification models

class obsidian.learn.convnet.ProteinClassifier¶

Bases: object

Class for specifying, building, training and testing diffraction image classifiers

Variables:
  • data_table – database of all available images with image path, extracted data and class
  • train_data –
  • test_data –
  • model – Keras model object
  • history – epoch-wise training history, created when model trained
  • split – number of data samples to be used for training (split fraction is 0.8)
Default parameters:
number of layers: 6
kernel sizes: min 3, max 100
dropout: 0.3
padding: same
number of epochs: 30
batch size: 20
loss weight: 0.5

When a ProteinClassifier object is instantiated, data_table, model and history are set to None to ensure that methods are called in the appropriate order.

build_model(nlayers=6, min_kern_size=3, max_kern_size=100, dropout=0.3, padding='same', custom_loss=False, loss_weight=0.5, name='classifier_model')¶

Construct and compile a keras Sequential model according to spec

Parameters:
  • nlayers (int) – number of 1D convolution layers (default 3)
  • min_kern_size (int) – smallest kernel size (default 3)
  • max_kern_size (int) – largest kernel size (default 100)
  • dropout (float) – Dropout rate (default 0.3)
  • padding (str) – padding mode for convolution layers (default ‘same’)
  • custom_loss (bool) – if true, use weighted_binary_crossentropy
  • loss_weight (float) – weighting of custom loss. A value higher than 1 will bias the model towards positive predictions, a value lower than 1 will bias the model towards negative predictions.
Returns:

created and compiled keras model
load_database(path)¶

Load data from pre-pickled database and extract separate lists for inputs and classes

Parameters:path (str) – path of stored data file
static make_database(data_folder, labels_folder, name='')¶

Load data and classes out of relevant folders and store in a data frame along with file path for each image.

Parameters:name (str) – Database title. Database will be saved as “namedatabase.pickle”
massage(split_val=0.8)¶

Massage data into shape, prepare for model fitting, populate member variables

Parameters:split_val (float) – fraction of data to use for training, the remainder used for testing
model_from_save(name='classifier_model')¶

Load a prebuilt model from file as instance model. Model must have an associated .txt file recording its loss function.

Parameters:name (str) – name of saved model to be loaded
plot_test_results()¶

Produce a plot of model predictions against true labels

plot_train_performance(history)¶

Plot evolution of metrics such as accuracy and loss as a function of epoch number

Parameters:history – keras history object containing metric info from training
print_summary()¶

Print summary of loaded samples and build model.

show_confusion(cm, classes)¶

Display confusion plot and stats

Parameters:
  • cm (array) – calcualted confusion matrix
  • classes – list of class labels
show_wrongs(n=10)¶

Display wongly classified images together with their true class and predicted class probabilities. Print wrongly predicted images in tabular form.

Parameters:n (int) – number of wrongs to display
test_model(batch_size=20)¶

Test model after training. Display training stats and test results.

Parameters:batch_size (int) –
train_model(epochs=30, batch_size=20, name='classifier_model', update=False, end=-1)¶

Shuffle and split data, then feed to model

Parameters:
  • epochs (int) – number of training epochs (default 30)
  • batch_size (int) – number of samples per weight update computation (default 20)
  • end (int) – number of training samples (default use whole training set)
obsidian.learn.convnet.main(argv)¶

obsidian.learn.metrics¶

Custom metrics for assessing and training performance of obsidian protein classifier

obsidian.learn.metrics.precision(y_true, y_pred)¶

Returns batch-wise average of precision. Precision is a metric of how many selected items are relevant, corresponding to sum(true positives)/sum(predicted positives) (see: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Confusion_matrix)

Parameters:
  • y_true – True values
  • y_pred – Predictied output values
obsidian.learn.metrics.weighted_binary_crossentropy(weight, from_logits=False)¶

Custom loss function to bias training towards a class.

Parameters:weight (float) – A value higher than 1 will bias the model towards positive predictions, a value lower than 1 will bias the model towards negative predictions.
Returns:weighted loss function
